text: hey guys thomas joseph here with another
kitchen conundrum now have you been in
this pickle before where you're ready to
make your favorite biscuit recipe and
you notice that you don't have any
baking powder in the house all you have
is some baking soda well today I'm going
to share with you what you can do if you
are missing this ingredient and you need
to substitute and also what these
ingredients actually are and how they
leaven bakes good so hopefully you'll
avoid the conundrum of a flat flaky list
biscuit like the one I have here so
let's get started what baking soda does
is in recipes in baking it reacts with
acidic ingredients so remember when you
were kid and you did those science
experimentally mix a little bit of
baking soda with some vinegar the same
thing here you'll see this is how the
reaction takes place when you are making
your baked goods so a little bit of
baking soda into some vinegar and it
should bubble up in foam and this is
what's actually happening in the baking
process when you're making your baked
goods these bubbles are released the
gases are released and that gives you
the lightness in your biscuit for
example now baking powder is a little
bit different it actually has baking
soda in it it's one of the components
but what baking powder also has in it is
an acidic component and it also has a
moisture absorbing agent something
typical like cornstarch or something
like that so baking powder all you
really need to do is to add baking
powder in a recipe that has some
moisture to it because that moisture
encourages a similar reaction like this
most baking powders out there on the
market are what you call double acting's
not only do they react when you have a
ingredient that has a lot of moisture to
it but it also reacts with heat so it
starts leavening when you mix your
batter or your cookie dough together and
then it also works when you put it in
the oven so there are two stages at
which the bakes good is being leavened
and to demonstrate that I have some hot
water here now the water that's the
moisture ingredients that will encourage
the first reaction and it's hot so the
heat reaction will also activate at this
time so sprinkling in
little bit of the baking powder you
should get this bubbling up and again
those bubbles create the leavening and
that's what gives you the lightness in
your bakes good now here's the conundrum
what if you only have baking soda or you
only have baking powder in your house
and your recipe calls for the other well
say your recipe calls for one teaspoon
of baking soda you're going to need
three times as much baking powder in
that recipe if your recipe calls for a
teaspoon of baking powder and you only
have baking soda you'll need to use
about a third of a teaspoon of baking
soda and since you're missing in baking
soda the acidic ingredient in the box
you need to add a little bit of acid to
your recipe as well so that would be
about a teaspoon of lemon juice you
could use yogurt you could use a little
bit of buttermilk as well you might get
a slightly different taste when you
substitute here but you will in fact get
that leavening that you need so there
you go guys
if you're ever in a pinch you have this
conundrum now you know how to substitute
and you know how baking soda and baking
powder work now right in the comment
section below or reach out to with using
the hashtag kitchen conundrum and we
will answer whatever questions you threw
our way guys
[Music]
you
